But then...The woman comes on board, learns from you of a German gunboat far downriver, and, lusting to exact revenge for the death of her brother, insists on the following: You outfit your boat (which happens to be your only transportation, not to mention your livelihood) with some makeshift explosives that you yourself must fabricate, take the boat downriver, through dangerous rapids, over a waterfall, past a fortified German citadel, to confront the much larger and powerful German boat. Along the way you must endure nasty weather, biting insects, leeches, danger from crocodiles and hippos, and who knows what else. If you happen to actually succeed in this wild scheme, and survive, your boat will be destroyed, and you will be left with...nothing. Of course, you may easily die at any point along the way, too. That's option "A."Option "B" would be to politely tell this lady to shut up and sit down. You will bring her to the nearest village or anywhere in the vicinity that doesn't pose too much of a threat. If she continues to insist on her ridiculous fantasy, you will leave her on the nearest riverbank, to the mercy of the jungle.As the riverboat captain, what would you do? Pick "A" or "B?" Yeah this isn't a hard choice. If you say "A" you are a flat-out liar. But of course, if you choose "B" then you'd have a very short film. So, viewers beware. The premise of this film is utterly ridiculous, not at all realistic. I saw this years ago in my youth and remembered liking it. Having seen it again now, it does not live up to my fond memories, nor its reputation as a classic. The entire reason for the journey is just asking way too much of the viewer.Favorite scenes (for the wrong reasons): At several points the boat is shown from a distance traveling the river and rapids, and it's beyond obvious that there are two dummies/mannequins standing in for the actors. Rigid and stiff, they don't move an inch as the boat gets tossed by the river currents. It's pretty hilarious stuff, but of course it's not meant to be lol.5/10. Would I watch again (Y/N)?: Nope. This will be my last time. The fact that The African Queen twice made The American Film Institute's "Top 100 Films" tells me the voters were drunk. It did drop from #17 in 1998 to #65 in 2007, so some of them have realized their mistake. Maybe next time, one can hope, it will drop off completely.

reviews.review_title: The chemistry between Bogart and Hepburn is amazing
reviews.content: It's a playful romantic adventure movie set in September 1914 in German East Africa (Tanzania). It follows a couple traveling the Ulanga River with the goal of destroying a German gunboat that harassed the British.Samuel Sayer (Robert Morley) is a failed middle-aged British academic who turned to Africa as a Methodist missionary. Helping him in Africa is his sister, Rose (Katharine Hepburn), a 40-ish prim spinster Samuel considers plain. One Sunday in September 1914, during their worship service, Charlie Allnut (Humphrey Bogart) arrives in a 30-foot steam-powered boat owned by a mining company. Allnut is an uncouth 50-ish Canadian machinist who came to Africa to work on bridge construction and became a general fix-it man for the mining company. He uses the boat to get supplies and delivers mail to the Sayers. Allnut tells the Sayers that war has begun between Germany and England and that they should be careful because of their location in German colonial territory.The German Schutztruppe soon arrive and destroy the African village taking away the locals to be impressed into the military. Samuel and Rose stay, but Samuel becomes severely ill and dies. Allnut happens by and helps bury Samuel. He then offers to help Rose leave in his boat. Their relationship is very formal; he calls her "Miss," and she calls him "Mr. Allnut." She convinces him to take a dangerous trip down the river to try to destroy a German gunboat called the Königin Luise.The rest of the film follows their adventures on the river and the change in their relationship after they successfully pass a German fort on the river. The movie ends with their encounter with the gunboat and does not match the ending in the novel."The African Queen" is a fabulous adventure story if you don't insist on plot reality. The chemistry between Bogart and Hepburn is amazing, and the comedic touch makes the film work. Indeed, the producers changed the movie's ending because of the electricity between the two principal actors. Much of the film was done on location, producing high-quality photography. But the magic is Hepburn and Bogart.

I had no idea what this film was about going in...a romantic comedy was furthest from my mind.I thought it would be more Apocalypse Now then what it is.  Just goes to show...don't judge a book by it's cover.It really is a lightweight film.  Very cute.

John Huston's The African Queen is one of those movies that you always hear about. Perhaps you have heard about it so much, you avoided the movie at all costs...much in the way that I did. How on earth could I have missed this film considering I am a major film buff and I am a sucker for these adventure stories. Also, I wonder why it took me so long because the films from the past half-century definitely considered this film a major influence. Maybe not Katherine Hepburn's finest performance, but I thought the film was fun and funny at times. Of course, why would anyone want to avoid any film with Katherine Hepburn and Humphrey Bogart?Considering the film was released in 1951, it can almost be viewed as an independent picture. Most studios passed at the opportunity to finance the movie. Producer Sam Spiegel, who produced many epics over the year, had the script in his hands and offered John Huston the opportunity to direct the film. Unlike most films made at the time, this movie was shot on location, which made it a high-risk film (which eventually did pay off). The cast and crew made this Technicolor film in both Africa and England, which is where the beautiful cinematography comes from. It was famously known that everyone got sick...that is the exception of Bogart and Huston. Bogart reasoned that he did not drink the water and only the whiskey he took with him. If you notice in the beginning where Hepburn is playing the organ, she is sweating profusely and looks ill. It turns out that she was.For the most part, the film follows two characters and is set on one location, the boat which was named The African Queen. This could have made more a complicated shoot, but Huston admirably handled it very well. Miss Rose Sayer (Katherine Hepburn) and her reverend brother are British missionaries living in Africa, spreading the word of God. This takes place during the onset of World War I, although they do not know much about it. They rely upon Charlie Allnut (Humphrey Bogart) and his steamboat for mail and supplies. Charlie is barely tolerated thanks to his alcoholism. When the Germans attack their missionary and Rose's brother died, Charlie rescues Rose. Charlie wants to hide until the war is over, but Rose is determined to attack a German battleship upriver. With these two different personalities combating each other, will they be able to survive the war...and each other?This movie gave both Hepburn and Bogart the opportunity to work with each other for the very first time. They both were excellent and had wonderful chemistry with each other. It is funny to see how excellent their performances are but are not even close to their best works. People got a shock seeing Bogart in color for the very first time and it is believed that worked positively towards his performance. Hepburn played a very determined, high-minded character and does so well. She won an Oscar for her performance.The African Queen is a simple, yet effective adventure romance story. John Huston commanded his ship very well as he does not go overboard with his directing techniques. Since the movie was shot on location, Jack Cardiff's cinematography is beautiful. Yes, that is the African sun we are seeing. I liked the film was set in the backdrop of the first World War, because it made for an incredibly thrilling end. The movie was more contemplative than I expected, so be prepared for that. Based off the famous C.S. Forester novel, The African Queen was adapted very well to the silver screen and I do recommend it if only to see the legendary duo of Katherine Hepburn and Humphrey Bogart in a movie together.My Grade: B+

reviews.review_title: Its immense charm wins you over
reviews.content: Here is a film made in a time when all that was needed to make it work was character, performance, direction - and a bit of goodwill from the audience. Sounds easy, but try and find all that in a Hollywood film today! I first saw The African Queen when I was just a boy. It was already 30 years old then, and dated, but its immense charm wins you over just as inevitably as that of the two main characters makes them fall for each other.Forget the impossible coincidences and holes in the plot, and forgive the politically-incorrect portrayals of the Germans and Africans (it was after all a different time, and no great offence was meant). This is a Sunday afternoon treat. Two great Hollywood icons sparring with each other on-screen - with another (Huston) choreographing it all from behind the camera. I agree with the IMDb reviewer who says it is not the classic it is often claimed to be. But it's damn good, all the same.

Ho-boy, Morgan Freeman really borrowed his method from Bogie.  From John Wayne to Bogart to Freeman, the cycle continues.  Stallone uses a similar technique, but he is regarded as a failure so we don't watch his method with the same attention to detail.This movie is unique because of how it uses Hepburn, making it more useful than other Bogie films (Sierra, Casablanca) but not one of Hepburn's best. It's all straight, a manner that today's movies don't dare presenting themselves as anymore because of the audience.The way the African setting is photographed resembles Florida more than Africa.  Still, there are a few clever tricks here to bring this out of the norm, but most rely in the pacing and not the script.Final Analysis = = Midrange Material

The African Queen is a unique movie in many ways. Most obviously, it's the only film where you'll find two of the greats of Hollywood history, Humphrey Bogart and Katharine Hepburn, in the same film. It's also spectacular that this film was actually shot on location, except for the in-water stunts, in Africa, apparently at great hardship to the cast and crew.What I like best, though, is that "The African Queen" has a premise that, while not completely original ("boat going down a river" and its variations being a classic plot in literature and film) is off-kilter enough that it this movie is a breath of fresh air, even 60 years later.As the film opens, we meet the pure missionary Rosie (Helpburn) and the light of her life brother and fellow missionary, who dies of grief after war erupts and the Germans destroy his missionary village, in an apparent bid to conscript the natives as troops. Rosie has no recourse but to cast her lot with Mr. Allnut (Bogart), the boozing river captain and only British subject she has contact with.Then the movie unexpectedly veers into screwball comedy territory, as Rosie, the innocent missionary, decides it's their duty as patriotic English citizens to convert Mr. Allnut's capable but aged boat into a kamikaze torpedo and take out the major German gunboat in the region. This launches them on a trip down some unfriendly (unnavigable, even) waters that is more funny than scary, which ultimately ends on an absolutely screwball high note.The film is funny and breezy, with just enough of a plot and character development that what the characters are doing doesn't come off as utterly insane, which is a problem I have with some of the more "out there" screwballs.It should be said however that it's rather amazing that a film set in Africa, with Africa in its title, only has Africans on screen for maybe 3 minutes, and that they have no meaningful dialogue. Ah, Hollywood before political correctness! Still, this is a very fun film and an absolute must to see if you enjoy either of the leads, or, as in my case, if you're a fan of both of them.

reviews.review_title: A good movie, but it's greatness is overexaggerated
reviews.content:
I saw this movie for the first time last night with my girlfriend last night knowing it was a classic romance-adventure movie and would definitely help me win over the heart of a girl and not bore me like chick flicks tend to do.This movie however didn't work.  There is no real emotions in it and the chemistry between the two often doesn't work well.  You never get attached to them emotionally and are never scared for them, because they are somehow or another ridiculously equipped to conquer any problem they come across and any other problems, that manage to go beyond impossible, are resolved by insane events of divine intervention.  I think a lot of people mistake this for a great movie because it has two great actors and overlook the fact that they just don't work right together.In the end it had some fairly heart-warming parts and some almost sad parts (which I think are essential for a good drama).  And the actors do their best to overcome an often ridiculous script.  It is a very good movie (at times) which has gotten a little more praise than it deserves because of nostalgia factors and idolizing attachment to the actors.
For a great movie, check out "White Hunter, Black Heart" directed, and starred in, by Clint Eastwood.  It is about the director of this movie, John Huston (Wilson), and his crazy antics while filming this movie.  It is chockful of laughs and drama and is one of my favorite movies of all time.

It was a good exception to see Humphrey Bogart so laughing. His role was different than usually, he acted easy-going way as Humphrey can. I've read Kathrine Hepburn's book about this film and I wouldn't call the movie bad because of their lack of chemistry, I think that there is some. And it is good to see especially a woman so dirty and without makeup in a film of old days. Some technical cuts should be undone, it's better to leave those kind of scenes out than make a dull copy of natural life. Story was nice when compared for an example to Bogart's To Have And Have Not. I think that this movie could be done better. Movie is a honest one after all. I like it.
An epic adventure starring the legendary Katharine Hepburn and Humphrey Bogart - Two of the biggest Hollywood icons ever.

reviews.review_title: With this Queen it was Never Going to Be Smooth Sailing
reviews.content: I remember seeing the African Queens on t.v. Several times during my youth and just loving it. Bogie, Hepburn, and the adventure of it all was just great. I I will never forget the leeches scene, that one always got me.Having seen it again 40+ years later I still enjoyed it considerably. Although not as unconditionally as I did the first several times. For starters both of the lead characters are a bit one dimensional, which i attribute to the script . . . Mostly. Huston has done some great work but for me his work here is somewhat pedestrian. They're in the wilds of Africa sailing down the river to blow up a German vessel during WWII and it all felt a bit tidy for me. Nevertheless, Bogie, Hepburn and The African Queens still entertains and is worth checking out.

Wow!  What schmaltz from the usually dependable Huston.  Storywise, Bogart is so pussy whipped by about the 2nd scene with Hepburn that the film has nowhere to go afterwards.  I heard he was some tough guy in this movie and then is slowly changed throughout the course of film, well that change takes about 5 lines or so.  Then, incredible redundancy ensues...Technically, I couldn't believe how poorly matched the shots in the London's Olympic Studio pools were shot to "match" the rest of the film.  Look, I hate special effects and am not usually overly concerned about technical particulars of a film, but this  was terrible and even inexcusable for its time.  Not to mention that it's even more distracting when you realize what they're shooting is them just floating around which could've surely been shot on location.  A real disappointment, unless you like saccharine schmaltz.

reviews.review_title: Lousy acting and 1950's camerawork are not the worst
reviews.content: Lousy acting and 1950's camerawork are not the worst part of this horrendously commonly racist romance war film... but don't take this review for granted as I only managed to watch the first fifteen minutes of this so-called masterpiece.

I wasnt sure if I was going to enjoy this movie but I ended up loving it! Bogie and Hepburn are wonderful together. I swear that man can play anything, no wonder he was chosen as AFI's #1. I love the part when Bogie is smelling Kate's hair. That made me laugh so hard, the expression on his face was classic, along with this movie.

Although I had heard a lot about this film, and even though Bogart is one of my favourite actors, it was with much apprehension that I began watching this film. I was not sure that I could sit through a film starring an actor and an actress, both supposedly past their prime, riding in a boat somewhere in Africa. I should have known better. For sheer economy in casting efforts, this film is unrivalled. It is almost unimaginable for any of today's  film to be as superior a product with as few actors and special effects. Both Bogart and Hepburn excel, and the ride down the river has a great poetic feel to it.Deservedly a classic!

I was only ten years old when this movie was released. Not a movie you would expect an eleven-year-old to be interested in - but I went to see it and remember really enjoying it. Of course I did not see any "goofs" when I first saw the movie. As an adult I find it a lot of fun to look for the bloopers and mistakes in every movie. You pointed out some that I did not catch. There is one other I did see. When Charley and Rose are on deck of the German gunboat, about to be hanged, their hands had already been tied behind them. When the boat struck the torpedoes, Charley lifted the noose from his neck and then lifted the noose from Rose's neck. Neither of them had their hands tied behind their back at that time.

Conceptually brilliant, the African queen, matching Bogey vs. Hepburn thrown together as victims of circumstance going against all odds, while managing to handle each other.  What went wrong.  Humphrey, known for being the tough guy with a soft spot for a beautiful woman ends up playing a backwoods dope with a soft spot in the brain.  Hepburn, always respected for playing the sensible but emotionally deep woman ends up coming across as a two dimensional character infringing her beliefs while refusing to uphold them. There wasn't a moment when I believed these characters were real.  Their lame adventures were implausible helped along by luck and `The Grace of God.'   The only way that you could believe in their `Romance' was because of their absolute loneliness and inability to be tolerated by any other human beings.  This movie is so hammy that you end up hoping that they are going to die.  What is seemingly going to be a gritty look at human nature ends up looking like the Wild Safari ride.  The only things redeemable about this movie are some great shots as Bogart is dragging along the African Queen through the marsh and some cool underwater opticals.  Perhaps I have been skewed by the brilliance of Apocalypse Now, but this movie is only good enough to get through.

reviews.review_title: Superb work by Bogart, Hepburn, and Huston
reviews.content:
At times I've been hard on Bogart for having a narrow character range.But he surprises me now and then, e.g. "The Caine Mutiny," and he does again here.Here's my breakdown:STORY:
From an overview the story is not that unique, complex, or involving sub-plots. You could
argue that it's like a one-room play about life on a small steam boat.But the story is unusual in the dynamic and evolution of the relationship between two very
different personalities --- thrust together for days into a tiny space. What gives the story
so much life here are the actors that provide that life.When you add the backdrop of war, patriotism, faith, and especially love ... you get a nicely
complete story.ACTING:
Bogart and Hepburn play off each other well here, no, extremely well. Only because each plays
his / her part right to the edge do we get this beautiful shape to the "odd couple."Hepburn is largely being herself, but that doesn't detract from her innate talent. Bogart is pushed
and pulled beyond his normal "I'm a tough guy and never show emotions" persona. I was (am) very
surprised that he stretched so far.TEMPO:
Very balanced between calm, happy, fearful, and exhilarating momentsCINEMATOGRAPHY:
Beautiful, if you like African / tropics sort of placesDIRECTING / WRITING:
John Huston ... what more to say? His skills and sensitivity were so far beyond his peers --- love (most)
of his work, though "Key Largo" was somewhat lame.Note: There's an old saying the "The fruit does not fall far from the tree," and it applies here considering
his father was Walter Huston, an amazing actor in his own right.Is it a very good film? Yes!Should you watch this once? Yes. No, twice.Rating: 8.3.

I have been watching a few films from 1951 lately and this is the first i have watched in Technicolor and it does come across as showing off a bit.The scenery is great and so is the detail.The scenes where the boat is in danger look very impressive for 1951.Hepburn and Bogart are both excellent.She plays a missionary, and he is some kind of drunk dirty sailor collecting post and doing odd jobs here and there along the river.It is set in 1914 and Hepburn and her priest brother are working in a Christian mission in German occupied East Africa, the Germans move into the village they are in and burn it down and her brother dies.In comes Bogart and his boat the African queen and Hepburn's plan is to get Bogart to make some torpedoes and blow up the main German ship that is further on down the river,Bogart for some reason just goes along with her crazy plan and most of the first half of the film is Hepburn just bossing Bogart about and they keep getting into danger, then she just goes back to bossing him about she must say "Mr. Allnut" in her posh slightly nauseating voice like 25 times.She starts getting excited about the danger and at no time does she come across like a damsel in distress.Eventually they fall in love and then the adventure continues with lots of danger. They have to work together to get out of it.The final scene where they are captured by Germans and sentenced to be hung but they ask to be married as a last request only to be saved by the African Queen's sunken torpedoes maybe convenient and predictable, but it doesn't matter these two deserve their happy ending.

By Far The Greatest American Film!This shoulda swept the Oscars. Every moment of this film is a perfect combination of writing, acting, direction and cinematography. If entertainment and visual expansion of the written word are the goals of film this one leads all others. Flawless.

In the most improbable screen romance since outlaw John Wayne wooed Quaker Gail Russell in ANGEL AND THE BADMAN, river boat pilot Humphrey Bogart and missionary Kate Hepburn battle each other, a river and the Germans before they find true love. The menace of nature and Axis occupation might have been explored more fully to heighten the suspense and danger in this place the missionary believes is not God-forsaken, but any chance to see these two actors at the top of their game overcomes any such minor drawbacks. Robert Morley is very good in his few scenes and there are a couple of crew members here worth a mention also. Assistant director Guy Hamilton and camera operator Ted Moore eventually moved up to bigger chairs as film director and cinematographer, respectively, and coincidentally worked together in those capacities in four James Bond flicks. It's not either Kate's or Bogey's best work, but it's a rare treat to see a pairing of such great superstars in a well-written and beautifully photographed film that's a treat for ear and eye. Be sure to bag this trophy in one of your DVD hunts. Dale Roloff

reviews.review_title: Dated and Hammy Acting but still worth a watch
reviews.content: I'm surprised this is rated as high as it is given how hammy much of the dialog is. It was also not so believable that Charlie would agree with the plan at the beginning.Also I didn't buy the modesty. They're 2 people in war, in the jungle, barely surviving. People might claim that's how it was in 1910 or whenever this was supposed to be set but I don't buy that. I think rather it's a bad writer's idea of what people in 1910 might be like. Real people through all ages get a lot more down to earth pretty quickly when in dire situations.Still the journey is interesting. I'm glad I watched it. But I don't see how it deserves such a high rating.Also interesting is how old Hepburn looks. This movie was made in 1951. In 1952 she made Pat and Mike where she looks 15-20yrs younger.

Maybe my expectations were too high since I felt rather dissatisfied after watching "The African Queen". One specific thing that annoyed me was the way how the main characters were portrayed; they were incredibly hard to warm to and therefore didn't make the watching experience really comfortable. Plus, their sudden romance was quite implausible and had a strong enforced taste in it. I admit there are a few nice moments, but as a whole the film doesn't live up to its high reputation.

reviews.review_title: Two in a boat not counting romance or the Adventures of one lively couple
reviews.content:
Adventure. The film adaptation of the novel of the same name by the English writer Cecil Scott Forester. Since I have not read the original book source, therefore I will evaluate the picture as an independent work. And I stumbled upon the picture by chance, and decided to see for the first time on the screen the owner of four Oscars, Katharine Hepburn, and Humphrey Bogart, who I loved (who also received an Oscar for this picture). And I was delighted with the viewing, not an explosion of emotions, of course, but this adventure can not be called an average person in any way. And here's my brief opinion for you-Two in a boat, not counting romance. I did not find any disadvantages in the picture, although there is one significant remark, which I will mention below, but for now I will describe the advantages of this adventure picture with elements of melodrama.So, here they are:
1. Scenario-East Africa, September 1914. The First World War began in Europe, which also affected the colonies. In one of them the monk lives together with his sister, they live quietly and peacefully until the Germans come and destroy the work of their whole life. As a result, the sister is forced to leave the house, and the captain of the small boat "African Queen", Mr. Allnut, volunteered to accompany her. Ahead of them are waiting for dangerous adventures, many obstacles and of course romance. The finale will pleasantly surprise you, although it does not carry any intrigue, the whole is guessed almost within the first thirty minutes. A pleasant romantic story full of adventures, performed by talented actors of the "old school", which will not leave anyone indifferent!2. Relationships - in fact, the whole picture consists of almost nothing but dialogues and relationships between the main characters - and it was possible to make it interesting, and even exciting. Their quarrels, common victories, defeats, solutions to complex problems - everything is interesting to watch and worry about them in every possible way, although we don't really know anything about their past, but we see their characters through their actions. That's right - two extreme opposites are attracted to each other and this killer couple will be able to do even the impossible. You can be sure of this! And the romantic line very smoothly lay down on the main story and looks logical, because the danger unites like none of the obstacles. The charisma of Humphrey Bogart and Katharine Hepburn play an important role here.3. Dynamics - despite the fact that almost all the action takes place on board the boat, the viewer does not have a sense of intimacy. On the contrary, you believe that the heroes really swim, and this journey does not go smoothly. Breakdowns, the actions of the Germans, the nature of Africa-all this affects the heroes, even their appearance, because we have not supermen here, but ordinary people who can be injured, who can get sick (for example, fever, which is common for Africa) and many more ways to interrupt their journey. I am sure that Spielberg was inspired by this picture when he created "Indiana Jones".4. Africa-filmed on location, so you believe in everything that happens. The beauty of the Black Continent pleases the eye, but they do not forget about the danger in the form of predatory animals, midges, water inhabitants. All lovers of exotics just need to see this picture.5. Music is far from a masterpiece, just an average person who gives the right mood here. For example, I barely remembered about it, because there is not a single memorable composition.6. Humor - I realized that it would be funny already in the first minutes - and the picture did not drop the quality bar, because it continued to make me laugh almost until the denouement of this story. The humor turned out to be simple and pleasant, although obvious. There is no rudeness, no vulgarity, I'm not talking about vulgarity at all, but there is simplicity and elegance - what else is needed for a good time in the company of the second half?Now about the remark. This concerns the brother of the main character-the reverend. It was somehow suspiciously quickly "leaked", and so idiotically, as if we were watching not a serious movie, but a modern cartoon for stupid children. I'm sorry for this comparison, but there are no other words to choose. Combined shooting and primitive special effects are not considered as disadvantages, because it was the fifty-first year.A little about the main characters:
1. Charlie Allnut, played by Humphrey Bogart , is a cheerful and cynical captain of the boat "The African Queen", who volunteered to help Rosie without suspecting that this decision will change his life. He is shown as a brave and determined captain, at the same time courteous and polite, who can be a real romantic. I liked Humphrey here, because he is usually presented as a cool detective in a strict suit, but here he is a kind of" shirt - guy", albeit with a trademark cynicism. Bravo Humphrey!2. Rose (Rosie) Sayer, played by Katharine Hepburn , is a very pious lady who has turned from a quiet person into a smart and lively lady who motivates anyone to even the most desperate act. A brave lady, whom you admire. This is an example of a strong woman, and not what today's non-feminists represent. Catherine pleased me with her acting. I hope that she will not disappoint me in the "Philadelphia Story" either.The picture became a box office hit, but it never reached the Soviet audience, which is a pity, because there is practically no politics here, and I am convinced that our viewers would like an adventure story.As a result, we have a good adventure movie with romance, a good script, pleasant and high-quality humor, the real nature of the Black Continent, and with a great acting duo of Humphrey Bogart and Katharine Hepburn!My rating is 7 out of 10 and my recommendation for viewing!

The enemy warship" Louisa, whose actual name is Liemba (meaning Lake Tanganyika") was built in 1913 at the Meyer-Werft Shipyard in Papenburg, Germany. For over 90 years the Liemba has been the only major means of transportation on Lake Tanganyika. It has been operating almost nonstop since 1927 as a passenger and cargo ferry after turbulent times during WW I.In the movie in common Hollywood fashion of demonizing the enemy" (or simply other people") the Liemba (or Louisa) gets destroyed by the tale's American heroes in an act of guerrilla warfare. This fictional story may work as an adventurous fairytale, but the attitude problem is quite evident. The enemy" does get reduced to evil and/or inept cartoon characters in millions of US movies, e.g. German troops (Raiders of the Lost Ark, Where eagles dare), Mexicans (The magnificent Seven, The Professionals), French (Two mules for sister Sara), British (The Patriot) etc., and the facts do get bent way beyond implausibility. In The Mercenaries" the Iron Cross of the German mercenary (based on actual German mercenary in the Congo, Siegfried Müller) even does get changed to a swastika. I wonder why John Houston didn't paint a swastika on the bow of the Louisa as well.Also remarkable is the fact, that the democracy" US of A seems to adore Kings and Queens; the heroic boat of this movie is a Queen, Elvis Presley is called King, Bush Sr. and Bush Jr. do reside and reign in an aura of selfrightousness like actual aristocrats in a hereditary monarchy.

reviews.review_title: This is the best of Bogart.
reviews.content: "The African Queen" belongs to that elite category of movies: CLASSICS. Released in 1951, the film stars Humphrey Bogart (who won the Academy Award for Best Actor) and Katharine Hepburn, and was directed by John Huston. It was shot on location in Africa under very difficult conditions for the cast and crew. In spite of that, Bogart gave the performance of a lifetime. Perhaps it wouldn't be fair to list the stars without including the African Queen herself, a run down old steamer that was held together with spit and chewing gum. Huston's direction was impeccable, capturing the beauty of the African jungle, the terrors of World War I, and the challenges of being a Missionary to the African natives.   Without giving away too much (there are so many twists and turns which you must discover for yourself), it is safe to say that this is a love story in the truly classical sense. It's the story of a relationship between two people that starts out of necessity and just grows and grows. It is also an "upper" in that by the end of the move, you have this warm and fuzzy feeling. Call me old fashioned, but I like movies that make me feel good. If you like stories that leave you feeling mad or frustrated, try watching the News. The bottom line is that whether you have just a few movies or a houseful, you MUST have "The African Queen".

Written by .. Reviewing Vincente Minnelli's 1945 masterpiece of impulsive romance, James Agee began, "The Clock (MGM) at its best, is so good that it inspires ingratitude for not being great." Agee's lyrical profundity was as entertaining to read as it was astute. In an era before the endless abyss of PR shtick and kiss-ass reviews supplanted the loftier ethics of film-criticism, Agee was the high water mark. Writing for Time and The Nation only seven brief years in the nineteen-forties, he introduced the modern form of criticism still in use, and influenced generations of writers. By 1948, Agee was dividing his time between freelance journalism and screen writing. His 1949 Life magazine cover story, Comedy's Greatest Era, remains among the finest essays ever written on silent film. Agee's genuine admiration of talent, and effusively positive means of expression, resulted in numerous, abiding friendships. Only recently discovered, Agee wrote The Tramp's New World, a post-apocalyptic fantasy, for Charles Chaplin, whom he fearlessly defended during the HUAC lunacy that eventually forced Chaplin from the country. Agee wrote screenplays for two of the most enduring films produced in the nineteen-fifties, The African Queen (1951), and The Night of the Hunter (1955). The latter was directed by Charles Laughton, who lived up to his onerous reputation, and Agee's participation ended in his acrimonious departure. Laughton claimed (after Agee's unfortunate death at 45) that little of the writer's work survived in the final version of the film. The Night of the Hunter would later be considered a groundbreaking film, through its use of minimalist production design, unforgettable performances (Lillian Gish, Robert Mitchum, Shelley Winters), and resonating moral message. Agee was far more successful collaborating with director John Huston on The African Queen. The film garnered several Oscar nominations, including best screenplay, and won for best actor (Humphrey Bogart). Huston and Agee, who became great friends, shared screen writing duties in the adaptation of C. S. Forester's novel. What remains clear today is the brilliance and insight with which Agee presented film analysis in a thoughtful, entertaining and informative manner, and the magic of his words on the printed page. His aspirations as a screenwriter, while depriving readers of his film criticism, were understandable given his immense talent, though unfortunate, considering his abbreviated life. Directed by ... The son of an itinerate stage actor and a newspaper correspondent, John Huston was a sickly child, dividing his time between divorced parents, bouncing from boarding school to fleabag hotel room. He became amateur lightweight boxing champion of California in his teens, and by twenty-one a lieutenant in the Mexican Cavalry. While in Mexico Huston wrote a book, it was published, and he leveraged this early success into a Hollywood screen writing contract, which eventually led to directing. His origins explain Huston's affinity for great writers. Throughout his career he collaborated with Truman Capote, James Agee, Arthur Miller, and developed films based on the works of Kipling, Melville, Joyce, and many others. Huston made his directing debut in spectacular fashion with The Maltese Falcon (1941). During his World War II military service, Huston directed a documentary account of the Battle for San Pietro (1945), depicting the conflict with such jarring reality Army censors cut it to half its original length. Even then the film evoked such a strong anti-war sentiment it remained unseen until years later. Huston's greatest success brought him two Oscars and a plumb role for his aging father Walter, as the crotchety prospector in The Treasure of the Sierra Madre (1948). Starring Huston's favorite actor, Humphrey Bogart, it was their fourth of eight films together. "Badges? We ain't got no badges. We don't need no stinking badges!" Key Largo (1948) later that year was a tour-de-force for claustrophobic gangster Edward G. Robinson, with an all-star cast, again featuring Bogart, Laurel Bacall, and Lionel Barrymore. Claire Trevor won an Oscar for her portrayal of Gaye Dawn, a pathetic, over-the-hill, alcoholic gun moll. The Asphalt Jungle (1950), based on a novel by W. R. Burnett, was a noir thriller about a jewel heist gone bad, starring Sterling Hayden and Sam Jaffe. It was followed by The African Queen (1951) Wednesday, February 14, 5:00 & 7:30pm The Historic Lynwood Theater, Bainbridge IslandBased on a novel by C. S. Forester, The African Queen (1951) is the story of two irascible misfits, thrown together by adversity, forced to reconcile their considerable differences for the sake of justice and survival, who inexplicably end up falling in love. Set in Africa as the first World War begins, German troops destroy the missionary outpost of Reverend Samuel Sayer (Robert Morley) and his sister Rose (Katherine Hepburn). Their only contact with civilization is Charlie Allnut (Humphrey Bogart), the seedy pilot of their supply boat. When Charlie finds Rose in the burnt out settlement after her brother has died, he takes her on board to avoid capture, and what begins as a plan to simply 'hide' becomes a mission of heroism. Charlie suffers Rose's starchy spinsterhood, while Rose comes to terms with Charlie's crude, slovenly behavior and drunkenness, as their humorous journey reaches its harrowing and memorable conclusion. Rarely do combinations of story, production and talent line up with results as wonderful as The African Queen. Two of Hollywood's finest actors, well into middle age, were perfectly cast as disparaged, alien opposites, with utterly hysterical and ultimately sweet results. Directed by an emerging Hollywood master, photographed by a stalwart of British Cinema (Jack Cardiff), adapted from the novel by a genius of film commentary and screen writing (James Agee), the enduring popularity of The African Queen fifty years on confirms why this film's place in American culture is as certain as water is wet.

Not really a War movie, though, that is the setting and circumstance (Congo - WW1), nor a comedy, even as humor is a warm undercurrent. Rather, TAQ is a love story. But this is not a romance where stars align, one so ephemeral it can unravel at anytime, oh no. The love that finds Charlie (Bogart), a "gin-drinker you (CAN) trust," and holy Rose (Hepburn), is a tested one, forged in fear & frustration, hammered to harmony in the heat of necessity. There are no dinner dates nor liquor to smooth the ride for "Rosie Girl" runs a clean ship. Instead, there are tea & teamwork, along with crocodiles & leeches ("little devils") as a reminder to the intrepid travelers that they are merely part of one, big ecosystem where all creatures compete, some of them German sharpshooters.Put off by the scruffy Mr Allnut at their meeting in the film's early frames, wouldn't the Reverend brother Samuel (Morley) have been surprised at the turn of events and how his pressed Rose had blossomed in her epic river adventure? I think he'd've been mortified, then proud, very, very proud of "Mrs Allnut." In peace time their love would've been ludicrous. War IS Hell, but even the Devil has to give its due to a determined duo that beat-the-odds, thrice: the Ulanga-Bora, Kaiser Germans and unlikely love (4/4).

Humphrey Bogart gives the greatest performance of his life as Charly Alnut,an odd Gin drinking man who lives on and runs a small riverboat delivering mail in Africa.He takes a prim missionary played by Kathrine Hepburn, who has been stranded by a fire which burned out her mission into his boat and the adventure begins.The unlikely pair eventually fall in love and strike a blow for England and the alias in WW1. One of America's Greatest Films of all time.

reviews.review_title: Gets Better as it Warms Up, Ends Up Great
reviews.content: Got more engaging as it went on. Basically, preacher's wife and boat captain in Africa must destroy a German warship to escape Africa at the start of WWII. Initially I wasn't drawn in much (religious missionary stuff is boring). However, as the theme of the movie became the adventures of Hepburn and Bogart through Africa, and it became clear the tension came from getting their ship through and from their relationship, I got pulled in more-and-more. Still not the most interesting setting for me, but would have been better if I'd paid attention right from the start.

I fail to see how this movie gets rated so highly. I can't believe that Bogie rolls over for that obnoxious shrew Hepburn! Don't ever Play It Again! At least we always had Paris. By the end I was waiting for them both to be strung up, with an extra rope for the writers!

The African Queen (1951), John Huston, is the story of a Christian missionary (Katharine Hepburn) who falls for a riverboat captain ( Humphrey Bogart) who is fond of liquor. I thought The African Queen was a merely "okay" movie. I thought the acting was done well enough, Bogart does a fine job. The writing was serviceable, but seemed rather typical. However I found the cinematography to be quite lacking in any engagement or creativity and that severely dragged down my appreciation for this as a film. It seems that it is just a regular Romantic Comedy that tries to play with a exotic location as it's main draw. It just fell flat for me.

There may be water on the brains, but this is a fantastically produced pic because of Kathryn Hepburn and Bogie.  They work so well together and play off of each other, and get soaking wet.  What a great film!  I have seen it at least a dozen times.

reviews.review_title: Romance on a boat in the jungle
reviews.content: Having read the book, I thought at first that there were some minor miscastings of the lead roles, but the second time I watched this film, I honestly didn't care. The special effects are a bit hokey, yes, but there's some unusually good acting by the two leads (neither of whom I've ever been impressed by because I just don't think they're that good, either of them), and a good story to boot.Considering I'm not overly fond of either of the leads, it's amazing that I managed to sit through this film, where most of the film is just Bogart and Hepburn on a boat floating down the river.Katharine Hepburn might seem miscast if one has read the novel and not seen the movie, seeing as in the book Rose Sawyer is described as a voluptuous, possibly blonde woman in her thirties, and Katharine Hepburn was a tall, skinny, flat-chested redheaded woman in her forties. Katharine Hepburn is exceptionally good in her role in that she manages to convince us that she is Rose Sawyer instead of Katharine Hepburn- even if Rose is a bitty of a nutty spinster like La Hepburn herself.Bogart's slightly closer to Charlie Allnut than Hepburn is to Rose Sawyer, book-wise. True, Charlie was a Cockney in the book, and not a Canadian, but Bogart couldn't do an adequate cockney accent, so they made him into a Canadian. Because of how oddly well he and Hepburn mash together, you don't notice his short-guy complex. Despite the fact that Hepburn was somewhat taller than he (she was 5'9).Half of the film was shot on location in Africa, and half of the film was shot in a tank in a studio. You almost can't tell when it jumps from Africa to tank. Famous scenes include the bits with the gin and the leeches on Bogart, but the scenes over the waterfalls and through the currents are very well done, too, even if with some of if you can tell that they're just sitting still in front of a screen playing a video of a rushing waterfall. It's less obvious if you just don't pay attention to it.It's not the greatest film either of these two ever made, but for me, it's the most watchable and the one I'd be most likely to consider a classic (along with Bringing Up Baby and Adam's Rib for Hepburn, and Key Largo for Bogart). It's a good popcorn flick, but also a tale of triumph and love on a river in WW1. Not one to miss, unless you don't like either or both stars. In that case, you'd probably be better off just reading the book.

reviews.review_title: Good acting and photography, but a rather poor script ruins much of that
reviews.content: The film has a very good reputation and is routinely regarded as a classic and one of Bogart's finest works. In my view, however, this is in an overall assessment overrating the actual quality of the film.The photography is quite good for much of the film; there are, obviously, lots of good shots of the meandering riverine area, and some of the shots of the boat itself are done very well (such as a rotating shot of the African Queen as she is moored on the bank of the Ulanga, or a zoom-out of the boat as Rosie and Charles think they are done for while they are, in fact, very close to their destination). The script, however, can only be called mediocre at best. It remained utterly unclear to me why on Earth Charles would ever agree to the plan - his doubts about the feasibility aside, he must also have understood that even if the plan succeeded, the boat that provides his living would be lost. Yet, this and other questions about the plan are never addressed, and instead Bogart's character allows Katherine Hepburn's character to boss her around while, at that stage, she has absolutely nothing to offer that he might be interested in. Add to that a lot of overly pathetic and schmaltzy dialogue - first between Hepburn's character and her brother, later between Hepburn's and Bogart's characters -, and you get a script of rather poor quality.Some of the acting was decent. Bogart does a good job portraying a drunkard who is, much against his initial will, transformed into a hero, while Hepburn does a similarly good job at portraying an old spinster transformed into a passionate lover. It's just not sufficient to compensate for the many other shortcomings that the film suffers from.

reviews.review_title: Don't understand what the fuss is about
reviews.content: Before I ever saw this movie, I had heard nothing but rave reviews about how this was the best of all classic movies, etc. I even read a comment from a celebrity interview (don't remember whom) about the celebrity not seeing this movie until he was on his death bed because it is so special. So with great anticipation sat I to watch this film!! And with great disappointment sat I at the end of the film!! Okay, enough silly comments, heh. IMO this was a good movie, but an average movie at best. I fail to see what can be so classic about it and wish someone would explain this to me. With a film like 'Citizen Kane', that film was amazing when it was first released and is still just as amazing nearly 100 years later. There simply isn't another film like it out there. Perhaps 'The African Queen' is truly too outdated to make an impact today. Was this film revolutionary in any way back then and if so, how?

reviews.review_title: Not as good as I remembered it...
reviews.content:
I recently re-watched the classic "The African Queen" on AMC. I remembered it fondly from my youth as a great movie featuring a lady and a cantankerous sailor who set out down a river in Africa, and *** SPOILER NOTICE *** eventually warm to each other.The movie does not quite stand up to my memories of it. Much of it is quite dated, and many of the scenes featuring Bogart and/or Hepburn in front of a backdrop (onto which is projected film of the water) are embarrassingly flawed. Perhaps within a budget in 1951, that was the best they could do, but a constant mix of scenes where Bogart and Hepburn are in a REAL boat in REAL water makes these inserted scenes look silly. The movie "Titanic", made a mere 2 years later in 1953, had none of these technical problems.In addition, the characters were not as argumentative as I remember them. Without much conflict about one-third into the movie, there's not much place for this movie to go, except, literally, down the river.
However, all that being said, it's still one of Bogart's best performances, his only Oscar, and is somehow still worth viewing. Rating: 7 out of 10.

I forgot how much I loved this movie until i saw it again. This is Historical Fiction at its' finest. Both Hepburn and Bogart are a delight to watch; and their charm just exudes in every scene. Bogart plays one of his gruffest roles I've seen; and both characters end up contributing to each other's arch's in unexpected ways. And of course the setting is beautiful, with very few speaking roles on screen for any length of time outside of the duo. Another reviewer mentioned that lesser actors might have brought this film easily down to a glorified travel tour, and i have to agree with that. If either role had been cast with an actor whose presence came across as weak; this would at best: be a very boring movie to watch. Fortunately, that's not the case here. If you haven't seen it, it is so worth the watch! (Now i have to find out how the book and movie differ. I can't imagine what they had to leave out of the film adaptation.)

reviews.review_title: Not bad...one of the better old flicks!
reviews.content: I had seen this movie when I was much younger and recently saw it on video. The on location shots are great and noteworthy. The basic story is interesting, but the acting style is outdated. An updated version of this movie would have to dispense with "obvious" role playing in favor of "real" people embarking on a perilous journey. There are moments when the acting and dialogue seem real, but they are nullified by many other moments where the acting is overdone or inappropriate. The first scene where Humphrey kisses Kate is TOTALLY inappropriate and awkward looking. It doesn't look real. The build up to their emotions would have happened much more slowly and naturally. This scene felt forced in order to establish the beginnings of a romantic involvement.The last scene where they were frolicking in the sea was another prime example of nonordinary reality. The dialogue and mood were totally inappropriate considering their dire circumstances.These old movies were made for a naive audience whereby directors and producers felt they had to sugar coat every plot and relationship. They did this to the extent that NOBODY seemed like a REAL person. Without real characters, how can viewer empathy be fully tapped? It wasn't for me in this movie. But still, compared to most old movies, this movie had a charm that made it noteworthy.

Of course Disney didn't make this film, but it sure seems like it. "The African Queen" is very much revered, and despite the legendary Humphrey Bogart in the lead role, it's a mystery exactly why.He even won the Best Actor Oscar, kind of a surprise. He certainly was good, but like the rest of the film, his performance seems cornball and forced. The whole movie seemed very contrived, and Bogie's romance with Katherine Hepburn being particularly rushed, forced and silly.The scenario, the music and the bad dialogue have "Disney" all over it. "The African Queen" really plays like a kiddie film. I almost expected Bogie to start swimming with the crocs as they help him tug the boat through the reeds, and for Hepburn to break out in song with the birds. Even the rubber leeches seemed like they were going to sing an evil tune as they clung to Bogie's body.So much of the film seems way too fake as well. Maybe the worst scene was when mosquitos or whatever they were swarmed over our couple. They were very obviously only on the film's surface. When Bogie threw a tarp over Hepburn to protect her, he should have also covered a big part of the swarm too, but no.Other obviously fake scenes were poorly filmed scenes with a miniature boat, and the obvious shots where they were in front of a giant screen. Some shots in the water you could hear the echo of their speaking voices because they are in a studio tank.But not to be all negative, because it is Bogie on screen, even if he's acting silly and saying bad lines. Hepburn even looks a bit sexy all messy, and thankfully her performance is a bit toned down. There are also some beautiful location shots.Best scene in the movie is when a drunk Bogie starts razzing Hepburn a bit. Best line in the film: "Well I ain't sorry no more, you crazy, psalm-singin' skinny old maid!"More drunken Bogie and some singing elephants may have helped the film a bit. Glad I watched because I love Bogie, but doubt I'll ever watch it again. It makes sense that this film was a favorite of Walt Disney, because this is totally a Disney film without his name on it.

reviews.review_title: This may just be because I love Hepburn
reviews.content: Bogart and Hepburn are an unstoppable duo in this movie. Most movies that are based off of books never seem to live up to the title, but his film by John Huston should make C.S. Forester proud. These two opposing characters create an interesting story line as they travel down a river in Africa. One character who is prim and proper juxtaposed to one that is unclean and unshaven make the picture automatically appealing. The viewer is entranced and wants to know how the relationship between these to characters will play out. I won't give any hints, but you should find out for yourself how it ends.

This is my all-time favorite Hollywood movie - Hepburn and Bogart at their very best.  The brutality of the Germans, bludgeoning the missionary and burning the village, starts Rose and Charlie on their quest through the unknown jungle, down the treacherous rapids, past the German fort to blow up the Louisa. Two people from completely different worlds face death together - "There's death a thousand time over down that river," develop great respect for one another - "You're the bravest man who ever lived" and fall in love.  The deus-ex-machina ending is pure Hollywood perfection.I'm not really sure what it is about this movie that makes it so great, but it truly is.
One of the best films I have had the honor to see. Have seen it many times and always enjoy it! The film, in my opinion should be ranked in the top 10 of all the films ever made to date!

Who would have ever thought that a movie that only focuses on two people for the whole time, could be this entertaining? Humphrey Bogart gives a brilliant, award worthy performance as the alcoholic boat captain. I first got this movie, because it took place during World War 1 and I was disappointed when I found out that it really wasn't a war movie. Once I got past the disappointment, I started to notice how great this movie was. Between the exciting action sequences, the top notch performances and brilliant dialouge and direction, this movie is entertaining from beginning to end. If you're debating over whether to see this movie or not, take my advice and rent it, you will not be disappointed.

For a classic of 50s its quite amazing to have such cinematography and special effects put together....frm todays perspective ther r so many glitches ....still the chemistry between the bogart n hepburn is truely amazing.....they both acted superbly....specially bogart.....the 1st minutes showing the africans in this way was truely nuts....but after all its a classic....

reviews.review_title: Moving wartime romance.. set in Africa
reviews.content: Based on the novel by C.S. Forrester, this John Huston film (1951) written with James Agee is set in German East Africa (now Tanzania) during the First World War (1914-18) and tells a love story capturing the spirit of that period.River boatman Charlie Allnut (Humphrey Bogart) is the most unlikely suitor for dedicated missionary Rose Sayer (Katherine Hepburn) but the situation takes an unexpected turn for the worse.Rose's brother Reverend Samuel Sayer (Robert Morely) succumbs to a tropical disease and she is left alone, bereft in wartime Africa. The war, of course, is in their heads until their village is invaded and burned by hostile troops who represent the very real, but distant war that is raging in Europe.Rose is forced to act, and with only the reluctant and slightly alcoholic mailman to lean on, she embarks on a journey that neither of them are fully equipped to deal with.But an unlikely romance is sparked from these desperate circumstances and between the two of them, they launch out into an uncertain future together in the modest vessel that is the title of the film.As the film unfolds, the prim and proper Rose and the rough and ready Charlie somehow beat one another into shape like a pair of blacksmiths working red hot iron.Without any precedent in their previous lives, they both find meaning and fulfilment in one another in a situation that is truly foreign to both of them.This film is an epic adventure for everybody who doesn't live there already.

There was a time almost a decade ago when I began to seriously doubt that a proper Dvd version -ie. Not a bootleg- of John Huston's THE AFRICAN QUEEN was ever going to see the light of day. But in 2014, Paramount (who only recently acquired the Americas rights) officially released a digitally restored print for the public. After enthusiastically watching it, all I can say is that the long wait was worth it. The color photography by Jack Cardiff was already breathtaking in 1951; the restoration makes it even more so.When the C. S. Forester book of the same name was first published back in the Thirties, Hollywood already expressed interest in making a film version. Several notable names were tossed around to play the two leads, but nothing ever came to fruition. The rights found their way back across the Pond where Romulus Films, headed by James and John Woolf, was determined to succeed where the others failed. One step in the right direction was enticing Huston to write and direct. The filmmaker was intrigued by the challenge, and when he wrapped up THE RED BADGE OF COURAGE, he and famed critic/part-time screenwriter James Agee headed to Uganda to shape the script together, with uncredited help later by Peter Viertel.With Huston and producer Sam Spiegel in the bag, further publicity arrived when it was announced that Humphrey Bogart and Katharine Hepburn would be playing the lead characters. A lifelong city slicker, Bogey already toughed it out with Huston on location during THE TREASURE OF THE SIERRA MADRE, and he was dreading the idea of shooting in the jungles of equatorial Africa. But Huston and Agee fashioned such a good script that it was difficult for him to say no to. Hepburn shared Bogart's apprehensions, but ultimately she signed on for the same reason.Filming on location in Uganda and the Congo was a tribulation for the cast and crew, where much of them were sick from malaria and dysentery. Hepburn in particular was so ill during the organ playing sequence that a bucket was placed off-camera for her to vomit in between takes. Bogart and Huston were the only ones to remain healthy all throughout the African shoot due to their daily liquid diet of gin and whiskey.It's 1914 in German East Africa (present day Tanzania) where missionary Rose Sayer and her reverend brother Samuel are doing the Lord's work in the Dark Continent. Their bliss is interrupted when German forces suddenly arrive to conscript the native men. When Samuel attempts to intervene, he is assaulted and knocked down, soon to suffer a fatal stroke afterwards.Now alone in a hostile world, the only other person around representing the British Empire is Charlie Allnut, a sodden riverboat captain whose vessel The African Queen has seen better days.

I consider this to be one of the best movies ever made. Unfortunately, movies this good can't be made anymore. There is adventure and action without ridiculous and overblown special effects. There is romance without unnecessary sex scenes. There is humor without silliness. There is no profanity.The best actor and actress of their time are on the screen, together, almost full time interacting through a story and script that are flawless. Although scenes of Africa and it's wildlife in color were not common when the movie was made, they are not overplayed.Anyone of any age who has not seen this movie should see it before seeing anything else.

reviews.review_title: One of my favrite movies of all time.
reviews.content: Warning Some Spoilers The only movie where AFI's number 1 screen legends male and female star in a movie together.Humphrey Bogart and Katharine Hepburn have the most amazing chemistry.Its a shame that they didn't take advantage of there pairing.One of the most beautiful looking films of its age.I often wonder how a film today with todays stars would look like in technicolor.I found Humphrey Bogart character very funny at times and his peformance was the best ive seen him.Katharine Hepburn is very beautiful and acted very well liked she did in all her films.The movie was nominated for several Oscars including best actress for Hepburn and best actor for Bogart which he won,his only Oscar of his amazing career.One of the best scenes in the movie is win Bogart wakes up with a hangover and Rose(Hepburn) is dumping all his bottles into the river.He tries to get up to stop her but cant because he has a monstrous headache caused by the hangover,quit funny actully.One of the most strong scenes is where to hide from the German army they must go through a swamp.Charlie(Bogart) has to get off and pull the boat where he gets a bunch of leeches on him.He goes back on the boat and has Rose remove them with salt,but has to go back in to pull the boat.Still his strength is not enough so Roose must get in to help pull.That night they become very ill,but are well by morning.And the touching of all the scenes is when towards the end where there about to be hanged Charlie ask if the officer would marry them first.Like i said this one of my favrite movies of all time.I give a perfect 10 out of 10.

Performance of Bogart is a real landmark in the role of a leading character. The other roles I can think of that might go very close to what Bogart gave in The African Queen are as follows:1. William Hurt in Kiss of the Spider Woman 2. Anthony Hopkins in Silence of the Lambs 3. Dustin Hoffman in Rainman 4. Humphrey Bogart in Casablanca 5. Uttam Kumar in Nayak Throughly enchanting and entertaining. Kate is also brilliant in her own way.

This is my all time, most absolutely favorite movie ever!! I believe it has a little of everything. Danger! Excitement! War! Drought! Storms and more!LEECHES!! Ooooooh I hate the leaches, and I tell Mr Allnut every single time NOT to get them, but does he listen?  No! I often wonder if the fact that I was 7 when I saw this had any influence on the rest of my life.I still hate leeches.

Filming "The African Queen" became problematic right from the start. According to the script, the main character, Charlie Allnut, speaks in a broad Cockney dialect and the film's star, Humphrey Bogart, refused to do that. Before the cameras could start rolling, they therefore had to rewrite the story so that Allnut became Canadian instead.The movie takes place in 1914 in what was then German East Africa. World War I have just broken out, so Allnut persuades Rose Sayer (played by Katharine Hepburn) to leave the country and travel back to England. The only question is how long the rough-and-tumble sailor Allnut and the middle-aged spinster Sayer will be able to get along aboard his run-down steamboat.Bogart brought with him his wife, Lauren Bacall, to Africa. There she met (and began a lifelong friendship with) Katharine Hepburn.The film's exteriors were shot in various African locations, creating major problems. In addition to the intense heat, the team was plagued by multiple tropical diseases. Behind the cameras, director John Huston was forced to place large buckets so that actors could throw up between takes.But fortunately, "The African Queen" was a great success at the box office. In addition, Humphrey Bogart won an Academy Award for his portrayal of the cantankerous steamboat skipper (Katharine Hepburn and John Huston were nominated). Despite Bogie's long and successful career, this was the only Oscar the actor took home.Not everyone in the film crew got sick, by the way. In an interview made after he got back to America, Humphrey Bogart claimed that he and John Huston were perfectly fine during the entire shoot. Probably because their only liquid intake consisted of pure malt whiskey.

One of the classics to see at least once in your life. Did it hold through times? Yes and no. Some of the action sequences on the water are so clearly made with a bad boat model, that I often laughed when I should have been scared. But this is also the story of a very strong British woman, Rose, enlisting the help of a Canadian man, Charles, and persuading him to take his only possession in the world: his boat, to explode the biggest threat to the British army in West Africa: the steamboat Louisa. The movie starts with a very lady like Rose, sister of the local pastor, forcing "civilisation" onto African people. Charlie is the local smuggler, and is a quite rough man. Their friendship seems quite unlikely, and their love even more, but though diversity and a common goal, they get closer. I quite liked this movie, and I do understand why it was recommended to me.

Katharine Hepburn (the greatest actress of all time!) and Humphrey Bogart (a legend, who won an Oscar for this film) are absolutely superb in this wonderful, romantic adventure! The spinster (Hepburn) and the drunkard (Bogart) travel downriver in Africa during World War II, fighting the Germans and each other! This film will keep you on the edge of your seat the entire time, and if you're not laughing, you'll be crying.This classic was directed by the late John Huston (father of Angelica) and filmed on location in the Belgian Congo, which is just gorgeous! I could watch it every week if I had the time -- it's that great and something I could never tire of!

reviews.review_title: We did not see these stars in color often before this movie.
reviews.content: Only these two pros could make this claustrophobic script work. This is an all time favorite in great color. I've always liked it particularly because of the fact that they both appeared in many black and white movies and they look good in this color film.Here is a film that upholds good values; patriotism, religion, giving up the bottle. Bogey utters the famous "And you call yourself a Christian?" when Ms. Hepburn throws his booze into the river.Some suspense and some laughs make this a perennial favorite. I also recall it as superior regarding technical things like cinematography.

John Huston has made some brilliant films (The Treasure of the Sierra Madre and The Maltese Falcon), some moderate films (The Asphalt Jungle and The Man Who Would Be King) and some terrible films (The Misfits and Annie). The African Queen is definitely one of those moderate films. A bit better than The Man Who Would Be King, a bit lesser than The Asphalt Jungle. In any case nothing to write home about. Nonetheless I was a bit disappointed. Not because it's Huston directing (he's too precarious to rely on), but because it's Humphrey Bogart and Katharine Hepburn acting. I love both of them. Like, really, adore. Especially Hepburn. It might be because of misguided romantic ideas of a lost Hollywood era. Or it might be just because I like the sight and style of them both. Anyway, both Bogart (who won his first and only Oscar for this movie and called it the best acting he had ever done) as Hepburn were not on their best. By far. Did Bogart get the Oscar because it was the first time he was seen in colour? He certainly makes a different impression when seen in colour... I liked him better in The Maltese Falcon, Casablanca, The Big Sleep and especially in The Treasure of the Sierra Madre. Same with Hepburn, who just seems sick all the time (which she partly was during the recordings). Compared to Bringing Up Baby, The Philadelphia Story, Adam's Rib and even The Lion in Winter her acting was often annoying and laughable. I get why this movie is seen as a classic, but a classic doesn't necessarily mean a good movie. This was just okay. No more, no less.

A very nice love story. Huston crafts the progression very crisply. Bogart and Hepburn are superb and I think Kate did better although he got the Oscar. You know it's good when as soon as it's over, you want to go back and watch it again.

I've always found John Huston to be a good and consistent director. This film certainly doesn't disprove that and while there are some questionable moments, mainly within the films opening 5-10 minutes, Bogey and Hepburn's chemistry is pretty solid once it finds its footing, Bogey in general is excellent, and Cardiff's gorgeous Technicolor photography graces the screen. Huston rarely missed, and this only further justifies that thought even if this isn't even close to his best.

reviews.review_title: shot inside a booth dialog for two
reviews.content: a great film for its time held together by acting alone. The trials of the river boat in Africa much different from "The Heart of Darkness" The tough fix-it Canadian Bogart matched up with missionary Hepburn proves to be a hot dynamic. You are sucked into the small details of character and the charming boat itself. Another war film demonizing the Germans circa World War one.I like to imagine this film shot in Iceland, near the coast with a lot of wind, very strange to think of the scenes with the mosquitoes then, the heat has subsided and the crocodiles would be and the bottom of the lakes smoking cigarettes or something.

The beginning of the movie was interesting with the moving camera through the jungle. It brought us to a Methodist Church within a village. There was much chaos at this point to where the movie wasn't grabbing my interest. The Germans come in a burn down the village and the church and beat the Reverend where he eventually falls ill and dies. Rose is left there with nothing until Charlie Allnut comes along and she leaves with him on his little boat, named African Queen. While on their travels, Rose wants to get revenge so they plan on taking down the big German boat with a torpedo. I enjoyed the special effects of the ship in rough waters. The use of the African animals throughout the film were enjoyable. The movie has a lot of misguiding scenes that takes you away from the aspect of the movie. The movie ends abruptly after Rose and Charlie and kidnapped by the Germans and she tells them that they planned on blowing up the ship. She believes that telling them the truth she will spare Charlies life. Only to find out that her and Charlie must now die. While they are preparing to hang Charlie the boat is hit and catches fire. Everyone flees for their safety. Along comes a piece of the African Queen boat portraying that it blew up the German boat.

Wonderful, a classic. So fresh and funny and interesting and endearing. I recommend it highly to anyone who loves movies. You can see how others have tried to imitate it, but this movie is just about perfect. You'll never be bored!!

reviews.review_title: Great dialogue and action. Bogie and Hepburn are fabulous.
reviews.content: The dialogue with sarcasms between Bogie and Hepburn is great. Hepburn has convinced Bogie to take the African Queen down the river to a lake where the Germans have a gun boat in order to blow it up. As they travel down the river with the crocodiles jumping into the river, Hepburn cries, "Don't worry Mr. Allnut". He replies back, "I'm not worried miss, gave myself up for dead long time ago." In addition, the early scene with Bogie, Hepburn and "the brother", having tea and biscuits is a riot. The leeches scene is famous and quite memorable. This movie is a must see. Bogie made many great movies but he was never better in The African Queen.

Available on Blu-ray Disc (Region B)UK/USA 1951 English (Colour); Adventure/Drama/Romance/War (Romulus/Horizon/Remus); 105 minutes (PG certificate)Crew includes: John Huston (Director); James Agee, John Huston (Screenwriters, adapting Novel by C.S. Forester *** [6/10]); Sam Spiegel (Producer); Jack Cardiff (Cinematographer); Wilfred Shingleton (Art Director); Ralph Kemplen (Editor); Allan Gray (Composer)Cast includes: Humphrey Bogart (Charlie Allnut), Katharine Hepburn (Rose Sayer), Robert Morley (Reverend Samuel Sayer), Peter Bull (Captain of Louisa), Theodore Bikel (First Officer), Walter Gotell (Second Officer), Peter Swanwick (First Officer of Shona), Richard Marner (Second Officer of Shona)Academy Award: Actor (Bogart); Academy Award nominations (3): Director, Actress (Hepburn), Screenplay; BAFTA nominations (2) (1952): Film from Any Source, Foreign Actor (Bogart)"The greatest adventure a man ever lived... with a woman!"When Germans level an African village at the outbreak of World War I, the unkempt, gin-drinking captain of a battered tramp steamer (Bogart) offers to transport the prim, spinster sister of a dead missionary (Hepburn) to safety, while she persuades him to assemble makeshift torpedoes in order to destroy an enemy warship downriver hindering the British advance.Casting is everything, with the gentle sparring of an uncouth Bogart (belatedly winning his only Oscar) and lady-like Hepburn turning a mutual dislike into tolerance, and finally love, as the repetitively humorous utterances of "Mr Allnut" and "Miss" transform into "Charlie" and "Rosie."Despite off-screen ordeals during its filming, a classic battle-of-the-sexes adventure.Blu-ray Extras: Commentary, Documentary, Stills Galleries, Star Profiles, Trailer. ***½ (7/10)
Don't know if Bogey deserved an Oscar for this. Many of his lines seemed deliberate and amateur. Kate doesn't help matters much.

This film was unrealistic, especially the relationship between Charlie and Rose. No bible-belt Christian lady who fall in love with a man like that over a period of one or two days. He was gross, I think. And while a relationship could've developed, the way it did would never actually happen. As far as an adventure film goes, I'll say it was decent. In fact it's better than a many few I've seen. But I am stuck on the relationship. It just seemed wrong and, well, gross. I was told it was because they were unlikely- they weren't attractive or anything. I'll say. Humphrey Bogart's front teeth made me want to grab his neck and file them down.

Everything was there to make this movie earn a 10 in an IMDB rating, but one thing at least held it back. Katharine Hepburn is an acquired taste at best, and I have never acquired that taste. Every character that she played, seemed like the crazy lady next door who forgot to take her meds Today. She brings the movie down, but may seem funny to children watching at least.

reviews.review_title: One of the finest movies ever made
reviews.content: I never get tired of seeing this wonderful movie. The blend of comedy and drama is flawless. The chemistry between Hepburn and Bogart. The last scene is priceless.

reviews.review_title: Imagine someone unfamiliar with Bogart and Hepburn watching this movie.
reviews.content: Bogart, a riverboat captain takes a missionary (Hepburn) down the river to escape WW1 German troops who have burned the village of the natives Hepburn and her newly deceased brother were ministering to.The acting is superb and Bogart won the Oscar for Best Actor. The movie does contain two clunker moments for me, the noisy stomach scene and Bogart's honking at hippos. Woke viewers may view the depiction of the local Africans as demeaning. I would counter that the scene of the young men wrestling for the remains of a cigar Bogart throws away which then draws other young men out from the church service, as guys playing around, just like they do anywhere. Robert Morley has a small role in the first act as Reverend Sayer, brother to Hepburn's character. He brings out the character's personality and humanity with much grace. The local Africans do a fine job playing the natives who are in turn, having fun at and being bewildered and terrorized by the foreigners' antics.

The premise is simple and time-immemorial: man falls in love with a woman, woman loves him back, they go through some hardships, which only strengthen their bond. What really makes this movie stand out, however, is its' storytelling.There are no long, meaningless scenes done just so the actor can get noticed by the Oscars committee. It is not a three and half hours long epic "masterpiece", so the director, in turn, can get noticed by the Oscars committee. In 105 minutes this movie manages to tell a more compelling story than most movies today do in 140, 160 or even 200 minutes. When you think back about the movie, you will think of the story. You will not think of the special effects (they are laughable), of how good the male or female lead acted (they were impeccable), of the music or some breath-taking backdrops (plenty of them).
